title: Contributing to MockData
text: Create new branch work: Make changes following coding standards Document changes: Update function documentation (roxygen2 comments) Add examples appropriate Update NEWS.md changes Write tests new functionality: Add tests tests/testthat/test-mockdata.R Ensure tests pass: devtools::test() Run checks: Commit changes following commit message guidelines Push create pull request
code: git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name devtools::check()

title: Contributing to MockData
text: Use 2 spaces indentation (tabs) Line length: aim < 80 characters, max 100 Use <- assignment, = Function names: snake_case Variable names: snake_case Constants: SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE

title: Contributing to MockData
text: exported functions must roxygen2 documentation Include @param, @return, @examples, @export tags Examples runnable (use \dontrun{} sparingly) Use Canadian spelling (behaviour, colour, centre)

title: Contributing to MockData
text: Follow Canadian Government Digital Standards: - Format: type: brief description - Types: - feat: New feature - fix: Bug fix - docs: Documentation changes - test: Adding updating tests - refactor: Code refactoring - style: Code style changes (formatting, etc.) - chore: Maintenance tasks Examples: credit AI tools commit messages (per project guidelines).
code: feat: add support for date variable generation fix: handle missing NA codes in categorical variables docs: update README with CHMS example test: add tests for parse_range_notation edge cases

title: Advanced topics
text: guide covers advanced technical topics MockData power users, including duplicate prevention, integration harmonization workflows, performance considerations. Prerequisites: Read Getting started guide document.

title: Advanced topics
text: generator functions check variable already exists creating : Without duplicate checking: duplicate checking: Current API (explicit cbind): Pro: Explicit control, clear data flow, surprises Pro: NULL return signals “variable exists” (useful debugging) Con: Requires col <- create_*(); df <- cbind(df, col) pattern Alternative API (auto-append): Function returns df_mock new column appended Cleaner syntax: df <- create_cat_var(..., df_mock = df) Planned v0.3.0 (breaking change)
code: # From create_cat_var.R (lines 64-68) if (var_raw %in% names(df_mock)) {   # Variable already created, skip   return(NULL) } # Dangerous - creates duplicate columns for (i in 1:3) {   df <- cbind(df, create_cat_var("SMK_01", ...)) } # Result: df has SMK_01, SMK_01.1, SMK_01.2 # Safe - only creates variable once for (i in 1:3) {   col <- create_cat_var("SMK_01", ..., df_mock = df)   if (!is.null(col)) df <- cbind(df, col) } # Result: df has SMK_01 (created once, subsequent calls return NULL)

Metadata preparation: Use recodeflow metadata format Mock data generation: Use MockData create test datasets Harmonization development: Test harmonization code mock data Validation: Verify harmonization logic applying real data Production: Apply harmonization real CCHS/CHMS data Faster development: need access restricted data Reproducible testing: mock data every time Edge case testing: Easy create extreme scenarios Documentation: Mock data examples clarify harmonization logic
code: # 1. Generate mock raw data mock_cchs <- generate_mock_cchs_cycle(   cycle = "CCHS_2001",   n = 1000,   variables = c("smoking", "age", "bmi"),   prop_NA = 0.05 )  # 2. Apply harmonization harmonized <- harmonize_variables(   data = mock_cchs,   metadata = variable_details,   variables = c("smoking", "age", "bmi") )  # 3. Validate test_that("harmonization handles NA codes correctly", {   expect_true(all(harmonized$smoking %in% c(1, 2, 3, NA)))   expect_false(any(harmonized$smoking %in% c(996, 997, 998, 999))) })

title: Advanced topics
text: large-scale mock data generation: 1. Generate batches: 2. Simplify distributions: 3. Minimize metadata: Large datasets (>1M rows) may slow Complex metadata many variables requires processing Normal distributions slower uniform continuous variables
code: # Instead of one large generation result <- create_con_var(..., length = 1000000)  # Generate in batches batch_size <- 100000 batches <- ceiling(1000000 / batch_size)  result_list <- lapply(1:batches, function(i) {   create_con_var(     ...,     length = batch_size,     df_mock = data.frame(id = ((i-1)*batch_size + 1):(i*batch_size))   ) })  result <- bind_rows(result_list) # Uniform is faster than normal (for continuous variables) distribution = "uniform"  # Faster distribution = "normal"    # Slower (normal distribution centered at range midpoint) # Only include variables you need variable_details_subset <- variable_details %>%   filter(variable %in% needed_vars)

code: variable,recStart,recEnd,catLabel death_date,"[01JAN2001, 31MAR2017]","[2001-01-01, 2017-03-31]",Death date death_date,else,NA::b,Missing # Load package library(MockData)  # Load DemPoRT metadata (has date variables) variable_details <- read.csv(   system.file("extdata/demport/variable_details_DemPoRT.csv", package = "MockData"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Generate death dates death_dates <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date",   cycle = "ices",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   seed = 100 )  # View sample head(death_dates) death_date 1 2016-11-17 2 2009-06-18 3 2008-06-25 4 2001-04-02 5 2007-05-18 6 2016-01-06

title: Date variables and temporal data
text: Date variables support three distribution types create realistic temporal patterns. Equal probability across dates range. Suitable calendar dates temporal bias. Use cases: Study recruitment dates Random calendar events Administrative dates Events concentrate near end range, following Gompertz survival distribution. Useful modeling mortality age-related events. Use cases: Death dates (mortality increases time) Disease progression events Age-related outcomes Technical details: Shape parameter (η) = 0.1 Rate parameter (b) = 0.01 Events cluster toward end range Events concentrate near start range. Useful time--event data early events common. Use cases: First event occurrence Early disease diagnosis Initial treatment dates Technical details: Rate = 1 / (range / 3) Mean event time 1/3 range Events decay exponentially Median dates distribution: Uniform: NULL Gompertz: NULL Exponential: NULL Notice : Uniform: Median near middle range (2009) Gompertz: Median shifted toward end (2013) - realistic mortality Exponential: Median shifted toward start (2005) - realistic early events
code: dates_uniform <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "study_entry_date",   cycle = "ices",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "uniform",  # Default   seed = 100 ) dates_gompertz <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date",   cycle = "ices",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "gompertz",   seed = 100 ) dates_exponential <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "first_hospitalization",   cycle = "ices",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "exponential",   seed = 100 ) # Generate dates with each distribution dates_uniform <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date", cycle = "demport",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000, df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "uniform", seed = 100 )  dates_gompertz <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date", cycle = "demport",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000, df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "gompertz", seed = 101 )  dates_exponential <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date", cycle = "demport",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000, df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "exponential", seed = 102 )  # Calculate medians median_uniform <- format(median(dates_uniform$death_date), "%Y-%m-%d") median_gompertz <- format(median(dates_gompertz$death_date), "%Y-%m-%d") median_exponential <- format(median(dates_exponential$death_date), "%Y-%m-%d")

text: Events concentrate near end range, following Gompertz survival distribution. Useful modeling mortality age-related events. code: dates_gompertz <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date",   cycle = "ices",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "gompertz",   seed = 100 )

title: Date variables and temporal data
text: Events concentrate near start range. Useful time--event data early events common. Use cases: First event occurrence Early disease diagnosis Initial treatment dates Technical details: Rate = 1 / (range / 3) Mean event time 1/3 range Events decay exponentially
code: dates_exponential <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "first_hospitalization",   cycle = "ices",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "exponential",   seed = 100 )

title: Date variables and temporal data
text: Median dates distribution: Uniform: NULL Gompertz: NULL Exponential: NULL Notice : Uniform: Median near middle range (2009) Gompertz: Median shifted toward end (2013) - realistic mortality Exponential: Median shifted toward start (2005) - realistic early events
code: # Generate dates with each distribution dates_uniform <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date", cycle = "demport",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000, df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "uniform", seed = 100 )  dates_gompertz <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date", cycle = "demport",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000, df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "gompertz", seed = 101 )  dates_exponential <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date", cycle = "demport",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000, df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "exponential", seed = 102 )  # Calculate medians median_uniform <- format(median(dates_uniform$death_date), "%Y-%m-%d") median_gompertz <- format(median(dates_gompertz$death_date), "%Y-%m-%d") median_exponential <- format(median(dates_exponential$death_date), "%Y-%m-%d")

what: Source format: simulating raw data imports
title: Date variables and temporal data
text: default, MockData generates dates R Date objects (analysis-ready format). However, real survey data comes different formats depending source. source_format parameter simulates dates appear importing different file types. analysis (default): R Date objects csv: Character strings (ISO format) sas: Numeric values (days since 1960-01-01) source_format parameter particularly useful testing date parsing harmonization code: Real survey data doesn’t arrive clean R Date objects: CSV files: Dates character strings need parsing SAS files: Dates may numeric (haven doesn’t auto-convert) SPSS/Stata files: Various numeric formats different epochs Using source_format lets test entire harmonization pipeline, just analysis code. formats represent underlying dates:
code: # Default behavior - analysis-ready dates mock <- create_mock_data(   config_path = "variables.csv",   details_path = "variable_details.csv",   n = 100,   source_format = "analysis"  # Default )  class(mock$interview_date) # [1] "Date" # Simulate dates as they appear after read.csv() mock_csv <- create_mock_data(   config_path = "variables.csv",   details_path = "variable_details.csv",   n = 100,   source_format = "csv" )  class(mock_csv$interview_date) # [1] "character"  mock_csv$interview_date[1:3] # [1] "2001-01-15" "2001-02-22" "2001-03-30" # Simulate dates as they appear after haven::read_sas() mock_sas <- create_mock_data(   config_path = "variables.csv",   details_path = "variable_details.csv",   n = 100,   source_format = "sas" )  class(mock_sas$interview_date) # [1] "numeric"  mock_sas$interview_date[1:3] # [1] 15050 15087 15123  # Days since 1960-01-01 # Generate CSV-format mock data mock_csv <- create_mock_data(   config_path = "cchs_variables.csv",   details_path = "cchs_variable_details.csv",   n = 1000,   source_format = "csv" )  # Test your harmonization logic harmonized <- mock_csv %>%   mutate(     # Parse character dates     interview_date = as.Date(interview_date, format = "%Y-%m-%d"),      # Calculate age at baseline     age_at_baseline = as.numeric(interview_date - birth_date) / 365.25   )  # Verify harmonization succeeded stopifnot(inherits(harmonized$interview_date, "Date")) stopifnot(all(harmonized$age_at_baseline >= 0, na.rm = TRUE)) # Generate in all three formats (same seed = same dates) mock_analysis <- create_mock_data(..., source_format = "analysis", seed = 123) mock_csv <- create_mock_data(..., source_format = "csv", seed = 123) mock_sas <- create_mock_data(..., source_format = "sas", seed = 123)  # Convert back to Date for comparison dates_from_csv <- as.Date(mock_csv$interview_date) dates_from_sas <- as.Date(mock_sas$interview_date, origin = "1960-01-01")  # Verify all represent same dates all(mock_analysis$interview_date == dates_from_csv)  # TRUE all(mock_analysis$interview_date == dates_from_sas)  # TRUE

Invalid date summary: Dates range: 15 Dates range: 0 Total invalid: 15 1000 (1.5%) Sample invalid dates: early: 2000-12-31, 2000-12-31, 2000-12-31 late: Range: 1-5 years start end Distribution: Split evenly -early -late Realism: Mimics common data entry errors
code: dates_dirty <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date",   cycle = "ices",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   prop_invalid = 0.03,  # 3% invalid   seed = 100 )  # Check for dates outside valid range valid_start <- as.Date("2001-01-01") valid_end <- as.Date("2017-03-31")  n_too_early <- sum(dates_dirty$death_date < valid_start, na.rm = TRUE) n_too_late <- sum(dates_dirty$death_date > valid_end, na.rm = TRUE) total_invalid <- n_too_early + n_too_late pct_invalid <- sprintf("%.1f%%", 100 * total_invalid / nrow(dates_dirty)) dates_complex <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date",   cycle = "ices",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   prop_NA = 0.02,        # 2% missing   prop_invalid = 0.03,   # 3% invalid   seed = 100 )  # Validation check stopifnot(prop_NA + prop_invalid <= 1.0)  # Must sum to ≤ 1

title: Date variables and temporal data
text: Use create_survival_dates() generate paired entry event dates guaranteed temporal ordering: Key features: Entry dates uniformly distributed across recruitment period Event dates follow Gompertz distribution (mortality increases time) Guaranteed: death_date > cohort_entry records Follow-time summary (days): Median: 3650 Range: 3650 - 3650 Mean: 3650 Add censoring simulate incomplete follow-: event_status column indicates: 1 = event observed (death occurred) 0 = censored (lost follow-, end study) Censoring summary: Events: 700 (70.0%) Censored: 300 (30.0%) Different distributions create different event patterns: Median time--event (days): Uniform: 565.5 Gompertz: 1000 Exponential: 302.5 Pattern interpretation: Uniform: Events spread evenly across follow-Gompertz: events later (realistic age-related mortality) Exponential: events early (realistic disease progression) Generate visit dates across study period: Generate realistic errors pipeline testing:
code: # Mortality study with 5-year recruitment, up to 10-year follow-up surv_data <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var = "cohort_entry",   event_var = "death_date",   entry_start = as.Date("2000-01-01"),   entry_end = as.Date("2004-12-31"),   followup_min = 365,       # Min 1 year follow-up   followup_max = 3650,      # Max 10 years   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   event_distribution = "gompertz",  # Realistic mortality pattern   seed = 100 )  # View sample head(surv_data, 5) cohort_entry death_date 1   2004-10-03 2014-10-01 2   2001-05-17 2011-05-15 3   2003-10-13 2013-10-10 4   2004-07-05 2014-07-03 5   2002-09-11 2012-09-08 surv_censored <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var = "entry",   event_var = "event",   entry_start = as.Date("2010-01-01"),   entry_end = as.Date("2015-12-31"),   followup_min = 30,   followup_max = 1825,  # 5 years   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   event_distribution = "exponential",   prop_censored = 0.3,  # 30% censored   seed = 200 )  # View structure head(surv_censored, 5) entry      event event_status 1 2013-10-25 2018-05-28            1 2 2014-11-10 2015-02-13            1 3 2010-08-20 2012-12-22            1 4 2014-10-22 2017-12-27            1 5 2014-04-29 2015-09-08            1 # Uniform: constant hazard surv_uniform <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var = "entry", event_var = "event",   entry_start = as.Date("2015-01-01"),   entry_end = as.Date("2015-12-31"),   followup_min = 100, followup_max = 1000,   length = 1000, df_mock = data.frame(),   event_distribution = "uniform", seed = 301 )  # Gompertz: increasing hazard (aging population) surv_gompertz <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var = "entry", event_var = "event",   entry_start = as.Date("2015-01-01"),   entry_end = as.Date("2015-12-31"),   followup_min = 100, followup_max = 1000,   length = 1000, df_mock = data.frame(),   event_distribution = "gompertz", seed = 302 )  # Exponential: early events (diagnosis, treatment failure) surv_exponential <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var = "entry", event_var = "event",   entry_start = as.Date("2015-01-01"),   entry_end = as.Date("2015-12-31"),   followup_min = 100, followup_max = 1000,   length = 1000, df_mock = data.frame(),   event_distribution = "exponential", seed = 303 )  # Compare median survival times followup_uniform <- as.numeric(surv_uniform$event - surv_uniform$entry) followup_gompertz <- as.numeric(surv_gompertz$event - surv_gompertz$entry) followup_exponential <- as.numeric(surv_exponential$event - surv_exponential$entry)  median_uniform_tte <- median(followup_uniform) median_gompertz_tte <- median(followup_gompertz) median_exponential_tte <- median(followup_exponential) # Baseline visit (uniform across recruitment period) baseline <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "visit_baseline",   cycle = "cohort",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 500,   df_mock = data.frame(),   distribution = "uniform",   seed = 200 )  # Follow-up visits would be generated relative to baseline # (Currently manual - see planned temporal constraints in parking-lot.md) # Create test data with multiple error types test_dates <- create_date_var(   var_raw = "death_date",   cycle = "ices",   variable_details = variable_details,   length = 10000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   prop_NA = 0.02,   prop_invalid = 0.01,   seed = 300 )  # Test your validation function validate_dates <- function(dates, min_date, max_date) {   errors <- list()    # Check for missing   if (any(is.na(dates))) {     errors$missing <- sum(is.na(dates))   }    # Check for out-of-range   valid_dates <- dates[!is.na(dates)]   if (any(valid_dates < min_date | valid_dates > max_date)) {     errors$out_of_range <- sum(       valid_dates < min_date | valid_dates > max_date     )   }    return(errors) }  # Run validation errors <- validate_dates(   test_dates$death_date,   min_date = as.Date("2001-01-01"),   max_date = as.Date("2017-03-31") )  # The errors list will contain any validation issues found

title: DemPoRT example: Survival analysis workflow
text: vignette demonstrates generating mock data DemPoRT (Dementia Population Risk Tool), survival analysis model predicting dementia risk. DemPoRT uses harmonized data multiple Canadian Community Health Survey (CCHS) cycles spanning 2001-2018. Dementia incidence (onset) individually linked using administrative data housed ICES – along mortality records censoring information, combined CCHS survey data. MockData workflow multi-cycle projects: Generate separate mock datasets individual cycles/databases (e.g., CCHS 2001, CCHS 2003) Hand analyst test harmonization pipeline (using recodeflow/cchsflow) Harmonize bind individual datasets using analysis code Calculate derived variables harmonization MockData generates raw, unharmonized data mimics individual source databases. pool bind data—analyst’s responsibility test. ’ll learn: Generate mock data individual survey cycles Understand multi-cycle metadata structure Test harmonization workflows mock data Validate metadata consistency Generate survival analysis variables (dates, events) Prerequisites: Getting started - Basic mock data generation Configuration files - Batch generation approach Date variables - Temporal data survival analysis

title: DemPoRT example: Survival analysis workflow
text: Load required packages:

title: DemPoRT example: Survival analysis workflow
text: Typically, need three configuration files generate mock data: Mock data config file (mock_data_config.csv): Specifies variables generate roles Variables file (variables.csv): Defines variable metadata (labels, types, cycles) Variable details file (variable_details.csv): Specifies distributions categories Note: mock data config file yet complete DemPoRT. example demonstrates generating mock data directly harmonization metadata (variables variable_details files). update vignette mock data config available. DemPoRT, harmonization metadata describes 20+ individual CCHS cycles (2001-2018): DemPoRT metadata includes 74 variables 669 detail rows. First 5 variables: ADL_01, ADL_02, ADL_03, ADL_04, ADL_05. Variable types metadata: Categorical: Sex, education, marital status, immigration status Continuous: Age, BMI, alcohol consumption Date: Birth date, interview date (baseline), death date (outcome) Derived: Age groups, BMI categories (calculated raw variables) Important: metadata describes harmonized target variables, raw source data. MockData uses metadata generate mock data mimics raw source databases harmonization. Multi-cycle structure: variable’s metadata includes databaseStart column listing cycles contain variable (e.g., “cchs2001_p, cchs2003_p, cchs2005_p”).

what: Practical workflow: Generate individual cycle datasets
title: DemPoRT example: Survival analysis workflow
text: MockData generates separate datasets individual cycles. bind together MockData - ’s analyst’s job test harmonization. Recommended workflow: generating individual cycle datasets, ’ll harmonize using harmonization pipeline (e.g., recodeflow/cchsflow), bind harmonized cycles together, calculate derived variables. Good luck! Key principles: MockData generates: Individual raw cycle datasets (separate files/objects) Analyst harmonizes: cycle using recodeflow/cchsflow Analyst binds: Harmonized cycles together analysis Analyst calculates: Derived variables pooled data separate cycles matter: Tests harmonization logic realistic raw data structure Allows cycle-specific sample sizes (CCHS 2001 = 130K, CCHS 2017 = 110K) Enables testing cycle-specific missing patterns Matches real workflow: harmonize first, pool
code: # Example: Create cycle-specific metadata files # Filter variables and details by databaseStart column  # CCHS 2001 vars_2001 <- variables %>%   filter(str_detect(databaseStart, "cchs2001"))  details_2001 <- variable_details %>%   filter(variable %in% vars_2001$variable)  # Save cycle-specific metadata write.csv(vars_2001, "demport_variables_2001.csv", row.names = FALSE) write.csv(details_2001, "demport_details_2001.csv", row.names = FALSE)  # Repeat for other cycles... # Generate separate mock dataset for CCHS 2001 mock_2001 <- create_mock_data(   config_path = "demport_variables_2001.csv",   details_path = "demport_details_2001.csv",   n = 1000,   seed = 2001  # Cycle-specific seed for reproducibility )  # Generate separate mock dataset for CCHS 2003 mock_2003 <- create_mock_data(   config_path = "demport_variables_2003.csv",   details_path = "demport_details_2003.csv",   n = 1000,   seed = 2003 )  # MockData STOPS here - hand off to analyst

title: DemPoRT example: Survival analysis workflow
text: DemPoRT survival model predicting time dementia diagnosis. section demonstrates generate realistic survival dates proper temporal ordering competing risks. table shows date variables temporal order. survival analysis focuses three key dates: interview (cohort entry), dementia onset (primary outcome), death (competing risk). Birth date included metadata age calculation required survival analysis . Administrative censoring: End follow-2017-03-31. Individuals alive date censored. create_survival_dates() function generates paired entry event dates guaranteed temporal ordering. must called separately create_mock_data() processes TWO variables together. Verify temporal ordering date ranges: Generated date ranges temporal ordering verification Real survival studies track multiple outcomes. DemPoRT, two mutually exclusive events can occur: Dementia diagnosis (primary outcome) Death without dementia (competing risk) ’ll simulate dementia occurring interview death 10% cohort: everyone followed death real cohort studies. apply administrative censoring 2017-03-31 (end follow-): Final cohort summary: Events, follow-time, temporal ordering verification simulated cohort demonstrates realistic survival analysis patterns: Temporal ordering: dates satisfy constraint interview < event < death Competing risks: Individuals experience either dementia death, Censoring: Individuals alive study end (2017-03-31) censored Follow-time: Varies outcome, censored individuals longest follow-dataset now ready survival analysis: Key takeaways: create_survival_dates() generates entry event dates guaranteed temporal ordering Competing risks (dementia vs death) require additional simulation entry event Administrative censoring applied based study design (end date) temporal constraints verified analysis dataset ready Cox regression competing risks models See also: Date variables tutorial date generation temporal constraints.
code: # Extract metadata for interview (cohort entry) and death (competing risk) interview_details <- variable_details %>%   filter(variable == "interview_date")  death_details <- variable_details %>%   filter(variable == "death_date")  interview_row <- variables %>%   filter(variable == "interview_date")  death_row <- variables %>%   filter(variable == "death_date")  # Generate 1000 individuals with guaranteed temporal ordering survival_dates <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var_row = interview_row,   entry_details_subset = interview_details,   event_var_row = death_row,   event_details_subset = death_details,   n = 1000,   seed = 456,   df_mock = data.frame() ) # Simulate dementia incidence (10% develop dementia) set.seed(789) survival_dates$dementia_occurred <- rbinom(   n = nrow(survival_dates),   size = 1,   prob = 0.10 )  # For those with dementia, set dementia_onset_date between interview and death survival_dates$dementia_onset_date <- ifelse(   survival_dates$dementia_occurred == 1,   survival_dates$interview_date +     runif(nrow(survival_dates)) *     (survival_dates$death_date - survival_dates$interview_date),   NA )  # Convert back to Date class survival_dates$dementia_onset_date <- as.Date(   survival_dates$dementia_onset_date,   origin = "1970-01-01" ) # Apply censoring: individuals alive after 2017-03-31 are censored censor_date <- as.Date("2017-03-31") survival_dates$censored <- survival_dates$death_date > censor_date  # Set observed death date (censored individuals get censor_date) survival_dates$death_date_observed <- ifelse(   survival_dates$censored,   censor_date,   survival_dates$death_date )  survival_dates$death_date_observed <- as.Date(   survival_dates$death_date_observed,   origin = "1970-01-01" ) # Calculate follow-up time to first event (years) survival_dates$time_to_event <- pmin(   as.numeric(difftime(survival_dates$dementia_onset_date,                      survival_dates$interview_date,                      units = "days")) / 365.25,   as.numeric(difftime(survival_dates$death_date_observed,                      survival_dates$interview_date,                      units = "days")) / 365.25,   na.rm = TRUE )  # Event type: 0=censored, 1=dementia, 2=death without dementia survival_dates$event_type <- ifelse(   !is.na(survival_dates$dementia_onset_date), 1,   ifelse(!survival_dates$censored, 2, 0) ) # Example: Cox proportional hazards for dementia # library(survival) # # model_dementia <- coxph( #   Surv(time_to_event, event_type == 1) ~ age + sex + education, #   data = survival_dates # ) # # # Example: Competing risks analysis # library(cmprsk) # # cr_fit <- cuminc( #   ftime = survival_dates$time_to_event, #   fstatus = survival_dates$event_type, #   cencode = 0 # )

title: Getting started with MockData
text: tutorial walks generating simple mock dataset categorical continuous variables. MockData uses two metadata tables: variables: defines variables exist database cycle variable_details: defines categories, ranges, recode rules tutorial, ’ll use simple example two variables: smoking status (categorical) age (continuous) . Variables table (4 rows): Variable details table (10 rows): Real survey data different types missing values. Use proportions parameter explicitly specify distribution categories, including missing codes: happened: MockData extracted 7 categories variable_details (1, 2, 3, 996, 997, 998, 999) Generated 1000 random values distributed according specified proportions proportions parameter gives full control distribution, including missing data codes Categories 1-3 valid responses, 996-999 different types missing data discussion making mock missing data see Missing data health surveys. Use create_con_var() generate continuous variables like age. happened: MockData extracted range variable_details [18, 100] Generated 100 random ages uniformly distributed 18 100 Returned single-column data frame added df_mock larger projects, MockData supports batch generation using configuration CSV files instead inline data frames. makes easier generate many variables . use config files: Generate dozens variables single call Easier maintain version control metadata Consistent recodeflow harmonization workflows Supports advanced features like derived variables garbage data See CCHS example, CHMS example, DemPoRT example real-world configuration file usage. Use seeds generate mock data every time. Result: TRUE - seed produces identical mock data MockData generates raw variables (direct survey measurements). Derived variables calculated generated data using harmonization workflows. Conceptual workflow: approach: Mirrors real data processing (derived variables computed harmonization) Allows testing harmonization logic mock data Keeps raw derived variables separate Tests complete workflow: generate → harmonize → analyze Common derived variables: BMI categories height weight Age categories continuous age Income quintiles income Health risk scores multiple indicators See CCHS example DemPoRT example complete workflows derived variables.
code: library(dplyr) # Define variables table variables <- data.frame(   variable = c("smoking", "smoking", "age", "age"),   variableStart = c("SMK_01", "SMK_01", "AGE_01", "AGE_01"),   databaseStart = c("cycle1", "cycle2", "cycle1", "cycle2"),   databaseEnd = c("cycle1", "cycle2", "cycle1", "cycle2"),   variableType = c("categorical", "categorical", "continuous", "continuous") )  # Define variable details (categories and ranges) variable_details <- data.frame(   variable = c("smoking", "smoking", "smoking",                "smoking", "smoking", "smoking", "smoking",                "age", "age", "age"),   recStart = c("1", "2", "3", "996", "997", "998", "999",                "[18, 100]", "996", "[997, 999]"),   recEnd = c("1", "2", "3", "996", "997", "998", "999",              "copy", "NA::a", "NA::b"),   catLabel = c("Daily smoker", "Occasional smoker", "Never smoked",                "Not applicable", "Don't know", "Refusal", "Not stated",                "Age in years", "Not applicable", "Missing"),   variableStart = c("SMK_01", "SMK_01", "SMK_01", "SMK_01", "SMK_01", "SMK_01", "SMK_01",                     "AGE_01", "AGE_01", "AGE_01"),   databaseStart = c("cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1",                     "cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1"),   rType = c("factor", "factor", "factor", "factor", "factor", "factor", "factor",             "integer", "integer", "integer") ) # Create mock data frame df_mock <- data.frame(id = 1:1000)  # Generate smoking variable with explicit proportions for ALL categories smoking_col <- create_cat_var(   var_raw = "SMK_01",   cycle = "cycle1",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 1000,   df_mock = df_mock,   proportions = list(     "1" = 0.30,   # Daily smoker     "2" = 0.50,   # Occasional smoker     "3" = 0.15,   # Never smoked     "996" = 0.01, # Not applicable (valid skip)     "997" = 0.01, # Don't know     "998" = 0.02, # Refusal     "999" = 0.01  # Not stated   ) )  # Add to data frame df_mock <- cbind(df_mock, smoking_col)  # View distribution table(df_mock$SMK_01) 1   2   3 996 997 998 999 312 472 156   7  13  32   8 # Generate age variable age_col <- create_con_var(   var_raw = "AGE_01",   cycle = "cycle1",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 100,   df_mock = df_mock,   distribution = "uniform"  # Uniform distribution within range [18, 100] )  # Add to data frame df_mock <- cbind(df_mock, age_col)  # View results head(df_mock, 10) id SMK_01 AGE_01 1   1      3     38 2   2      1     77 3   3      2     52 4   4      2     40 5   5      2     94 6   6      1     38 7   7      1     59 8   8      3     59 9   9      2     70 10 10      2     69 summary(df_mock$AGE_01) Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu. title: Getting started with MockData
text: MockData uses two metadata tables: variables: defines variables exist database cycle variable_details: defines categories, ranges, recode rules tutorial, ’ll use simple example two variables: smoking status (categorical) age (continuous) . Variables table (4 rows): Variable details table (10 rows):
code: # Define variables table variables <- data.frame(   variable = c("smoking", "smoking", "age", "age"),   variableStart = c("SMK_01", "SMK_01", "AGE_01", "AGE_01"),   databaseStart = c("cycle1", "cycle2", "cycle1", "cycle2"),   databaseEnd = c("cycle1", "cycle2", "cycle1", "cycle2"),   variableType = c("categorical", "categorical", "continuous", "continuous") )  # Define variable details (categories and ranges) variable_details <- data.frame(   variable = c("smoking", "smoking", "smoking",                "smoking", "smoking", "smoking", "smoking",                "age", "age", "age"),   recStart = c("1", "2", "3", "996", "997", "998", "999",                "[18, 100]", "996", "[997, 999]"),   recEnd = c("1", "2", "3", "996", "997", "998", "999",              "copy", "NA::a", "NA::b"),   catLabel = c("Daily smoker", "Occasional smoker", "Never smoked",                "Not applicable", "Don't know", "Refusal", "Not stated",                "Age in years", "Not applicable", "Missing"),   variableStart = c("SMK_01", "SMK_01", "SMK_01", "SMK_01", "SMK_01", "SMK_01", "SMK_01",                     "AGE_01", "AGE_01", "AGE_01"),   databaseStart = c("cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1",                     "cycle1", "cycle1", "cycle1"),   rType = c("factor", "factor", "factor", "factor", "factor", "factor", "factor",             "integer", "integer", "integer") )

what: Step 2: Generate a categorical variable with custom proportions
title: Getting started with MockData
text: Real survey data different types missing values. Use proportions parameter explicitly specify distribution categories, including missing codes: happened: MockData extracted 7 categories variable_details (1, 2, 3, 996, 997, 998, 999) Generated 1000 random values distributed according specified proportions proportions parameter gives full control distribution, including missing data codes Categories 1-3 valid responses, 996-999 different types missing data discussion making mock missing data see Missing data health surveys.
code: # Create mock data frame df_mock <- data.frame(id = 1:1000)  # Generate smoking variable with explicit proportions for ALL categories smoking_col <- create_cat_var(   var_raw = "SMK_01",   cycle = "cycle1",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 1000,   df_mock = df_mock,   proportions = list(     "1" = 0.30,   # Daily smoker     "2" = 0.50,   # Occasional smoker     "3" = 0.15,   # Never smoked     "996" = 0.01, # Not applicable (valid skip)     "997" = 0.01, # Don't know     "998" = 0.02, # Refusal     "999" = 0.01  # Not stated   ) )  # Add to data frame df_mock <- cbind(df_mock, smoking_col)  # View distribution table(df_mock$SMK_01) 1   2   3 996 997 998 999 312 472 156   7  13  32   8

title: Getting started with MockData
text: Use create_con_var() generate continuous variables like age. happened: MockData extracted range variable_details [18, 100] Generated 100 random ages uniformly distributed 18 100 Returned single-column data frame added df_mock
code: # Generate age variable age_col <- create_con_var(   var_raw = "AGE_01",   cycle = "cycle1",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 100,   df_mock = df_mock,   distribution = "uniform"  # Uniform distribution within range [18, 100] )  # Add to data frame df_mock <- cbind(df_mock, age_col)  # View results head(df_mock, 10) id SMK_01 AGE_01 1   1      3     38 2   2      1     77 3   3      2     52 4   4      2     40 5   5      2     94 6   6      1     38 7   7      1     59 8   8      3     59 9   9      2     70 10 10      2     69 summary(df_mock$AGE_01) Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.   18.00   40.00   63.50   60.93   79.25   99.00

title: Getting started with MockData
text: larger projects, MockData supports batch generation using configuration CSV files instead inline data frames. makes easier generate many variables . use config files: Generate dozens variables single call Easier maintain version control metadata Consistent recodeflow harmonization workflows Supports advanced features like derived variables garbage data See CCHS example, CHMS example, DemPoRT example real-world configuration file usage.
code: # Read configuration files (not run in this tutorial) config <- read_mock_data_config("mock_data_config.csv") details <- read_mock_data_config_details("mock_data_config_details.csv")  # Generate all variables in one call mock_data <- create_mock_data(   config = config,   details = details,   n = 1000,   seed = 123 )

title: Getting started with MockData
text: Use seeds generate mock data every time. Result: TRUE - seed produces identical mock data
code: # Set seed for reproducibility set.seed(12345)  df_mock <- data.frame(id = 1:100)  result1 <- create_cat_var(   var_raw = "SMK_01",   cycle = "cycle1",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 100,   df_mock = df_mock )  # Reset seed set.seed(12345)  df_mock <- data.frame(id = 1:100)  result2 <- create_cat_var(   var_raw = "SMK_01",   cycle = "cycle1",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 100,   df_mock = df_mock )  # Verify identical identical(result1$SMK_01, result2$SMK_01) [1] TRUE

title: Getting started with MockData
text: MockData generates raw variables (direct survey measurements). Derived variables calculated generated data using harmonization workflows. Conceptual workflow: approach: Mirrors real data processing (derived variables computed harmonization) Allows testing harmonization logic mock data Keeps raw derived variables separate Tests complete workflow: generate → harmonize → analyze Common derived variables: BMI categories height weight Age categories continuous age Income quintiles income Health risk scores multiple indicators See CCHS example DemPoRT example complete workflows derived variables.
code: # 1. Generate mock raw variables mock_data <- create_mock_data(   config = config,        # Includes height_raw, weight_raw   details = details,   n = 1000 )  # 2. Apply harmonization to create derived variables # (Requires cchsflow or recodeflow package) # library(cchsflow) # mock_data <- rec_with_table( #   data = mock_data, #   variables = variables, #   variable_details = variable_details, #   database_name = "cchs2001" # ) # Now mock_data includes derived variables like BMI_der, age categories, etc.

title: Configuration reference
text: Note NA:: codes: codes (NA::, NA::b, NA::c) part recodeflow harmonization framework, indicate missing codes transformed harmonization. generating raw mock data, use numeric missing codes match raw survey data format. However, NA:: notation handy metadata : documents meaning numeric missing codes metadata can reused mock data generation (outputs numeric codes) harmonization (converts codes proper R NA types) maintains consistency raw data simulation harmonization pipeline Important: specific numeric codes (996, 997, 998, 999) shown examples CCHS/CHMS surveys documented package. database may use different codes: - surveys use single digits: 7, 8, 9 - use three digits: 997, 998, 999 - use ranges: [96, 99] - Check survey’s data dictionary actual codes used NA:: notation works numeric coding scheme - just specify appropriate numeric codes recStart. Example - generates numeric codes raw mock data: generate raw data numeric values 0-100, 996, 999. harmonization recodeflow, 996 999 codes converted proper R NA values based NA::NA::b specifications. Example: Example: Important: Garbage proportions SEPARATE valid+missing proportions. MockData first allocates values valid vs missing (must sum 1.0), applies garbage subset valid values.

title: Configuration reference
text: Inclusive ranges (endpoints included): Range notation: [, b]: Inclusive ends (≤ x ≤ b) [, b): Inclusive start, exclusive end (≤ x < b) (, b]: Exclusive start, inclusive end (< x ≤ b) (, b): Exclusive ends (< x < b) categorical variables: Ranges expand integer values continuous variables: Ranges define sampling bounds Raw data format: Real survey data (like CCHS/CHMS) stores dates SAS format (e.g., 01JAN2001). MockData can parse formats recStart: Output format controlled source_format parameter: default, MockData generates dates R Date objects (analysis-ready format). However, can simulate different source formats test harmonization pipelines: Format options: "analysis" (default): R Date objects - ready analysis "csv": Character strings ("2001-01-15") - simulates read.csv() output "sas": Numeric values (days since 1960-01-01) - simulates haven::read_sas() output Use case: Testing harmonization code needs parse dates raw sources: See Date variables temporal data detailed examples. Alternative approach using date_start/date_end columns: metadata approaches (SAS format recStart vs. date_start/date_end columns) work source_format options.
code: recStart,recEnd,Meaning 1,1,Value 1 2,2,Value 2 999,NA::b,Code 999 becomes missing recStart,Meaning [0,100],Values from 0 to 100 inclusive [18.5,25),Values from 18.5 (inclusive) to 25 (exclusive) recStart,recEnd,Expands to [1,5],copy,"1, 2, 3, 4, 5" recStart,recEnd,Generates [0,100],copy,Random values uniformly distributed between 0 and 100 recStart,recEnd,Meaning [01JAN2001,31MAR2017],copy,Dates between Jan 1 2001 and Mar 31 2017 # Default: analysis-ready R Date objects mock <- create_mock_data(..., source_format = "analysis")  # CSV format: character ISO strings mock_csv <- create_mock_data(..., source_format = "csv")  # SAS format: numeric (days since 1960-01-01) mock_sas <- create_mock_data(..., source_format = "sas") # Generate CSV-format mock data mock_csv <- create_mock_data(..., source_format = "csv")  # Test your date parsing logic harmonized <- mock_csv %>%   mutate(interview_date = as.Date(interview_date, format = "%Y-%m-%d")) variable,recStart,recEnd,date_start,date_end,proportion death_date,NA,date_start,2001-01-01,,1.0 death_date,NA,date_end,,2017-03-31,1.0

text: Must sum 1.0 per variable (excluding garbage rows) Garbage proportions separate valid/missing proportions Applies population garbage added Sum check: 0.25 + 0.15 + 0.55 + 0.05 = 1.0 ✓ Interpretation: 95% values: sampled uniformly [18, 100] 5% values: set 999, converted NA Process: Generate population: 95% valid (18-100), 5% missing (999→NA) Apply garbage: Replace 2% valid values corrupt_high (200-300) Result: ~93% valid, ~5% missing, ~2% garbage

title: Generating datasets from configuration files
text: MockData takes metadata-driven approach differs synthetic data packages: synthetic data packages: Specify distributions directly code MockData: Define data structure metadata files, reuse harmonization mock data generation Benefits metadata-driven approach: Reuse existing recodeflow metadata - need duplicate variable definitions Single source truth - Variable structure defined , used everywhere Consistency harmonization - Mock data matches real data structure exactly Easy maintain - Update metadata , affects harmonization mock data Version control friendly - Metadata files work well git use configuration files: Many variables generate (5+) Existing recodeflow metadata harmonization projects Need match published descriptive statistics (“Table 1”) Reproducible workflows version-controlled metadata Alternative approach: learning working just variables, see Getting started variable--variable approach.
code: # Typical approach in other packages synthetic_data <- generate_data(   age = normal(mean = 55, sd = 15),   smoking = categorical(probs = c(0.3, 0.5, 0.2)) ) # MockData approach mock_data <- create_mock_data(   config_path = "variables.csv",   details_path = "variable_details.csv",   n = 1000 )

title: Generating datasets from configuration files
code: library(dplyr) library(MockData)

title: Generating datasets from configuration files
text: tutorial show use columns step--step. ’s quick reference later: Configuration file (variables.csv): Details file (variable_details.csv): Common recEnd values: "copy" - Pass value recStart (use ranges like “[18,100]”) recStart - Output specific value (e.g., “1”, “2”, “999”) "corrupt_high" / "corrupt_low" - Generate garbage data specified range "mean" / "sd" - Specify normal distribution parameters (advanced)

title: Generating datasets from configuration files
text: Let’s start simplest possible example: single categorical variable. shows basic pattern ’ll use variables. configuration file lists variables generate: Configuration table (1 row): Key columns: uid: Unique identifier variable definition variable: Variable name (becomes column name output) role: Set “enabled” generate variable (dates, use role like “baseline-date”) variableType: “categorical” “continuous” (dates use “continuous” + role recodeflow compatibility) position: Order variables generated (1 = first, 2 = second, etc.) Note stringsAsFactors = FALSE: R parameter prevents automatic conversion character columns factors creating data frames. Always set FALSE preserve exact data types specify. details file specifies values variable can : Details table (3 rows): Key columns: uid: Must match uid config file uid_detail: Unique identifier detail row variable: Must match variable name config categorical: Category codes like “1”, “2”, “3” continuous: Ranges like “[18, 100]” missing codes like “999” dates: Date ranges like “[1950-01-01, 2000-12-31]” “copy” = pass value recStart recStart = output specific value (e.g., “1”, “999”) “corrupt_high” / “corrupt_low” = generate garbage data catLabel: Short label category proportion: Optional proportion category (must sum 1.0 within variable) rType: Optional R data type output (e.g., “integer”, “factor”, “Date”) create_mock_data() parameters: config_path: Path CSV file listing variables generate details_path: Path CSV file specifying variable structure (categories, ranges, proportions) n: Number observations (rows) generate seed: Random seed reproducibility - seed always produces identical data verbose: Set FALSE suppress informational messages generation (useful cleaner output reports) validate: Optional, defaults TRUE - validates metadata generation happened: MockData read files understand variable structure Generated 100 random values {1, 2, 3} uniform distribution Returned data frame one column: smoking
code: # Start with just smoking status config <- data.frame(   uid = "smoking_v1",   variable = "smoking",   role = "enabled",   variableType = "categorical",   variableLabel = "Smoking status",   position = 1,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE ) # Define the three categories details <- data.frame(   uid = c("smoking_v1", "smoking_v1", "smoking_v1"),   uid_detail = c("smoking_v1_d1", "smoking_v1_d2", "smoking_v1_d3"),   variable = c("smoking", "smoking", "smoking"),   recStart = c("1", "2", "3"),   recEnd = c("1", "2", "3"),   catLabel = c("Daily smoker", "Occasional smoker", "Never smoked"),   catLabelLong = c("Smokes daily", "Smokes occasionally", "Never smoked"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE ) # create_mock_data() reads CSV files, so we need to save our data.frames first temp_config <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") temp_details <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") write.csv(config, temp_config, row.names = FALSE) write.csv(details, temp_details, row.names = FALSE)  # Generate 100 observations mock_data <- create_mock_data(   config_path = temp_config,    # Path to configuration CSV   details_path = temp_details,  # Path to variable details CSV   n = 100,                      # Number of observations to generate   seed = 123,                   # Random seed for reproducibility   verbose = FALSE               # Suppress progress messages )  # Clean up temp files unlink(c(temp_config, temp_details))  # View the data head(mock_data, 10) smoking 1        2 2        1 3        3 4        1 5        1 6        2 7        3 8        1 9        3 10       3 table(mock_data$smoking) 1  2  3 33 33 34

what: Step 3: Generate your first mock dataset
title: Generating datasets from configuration files
text: create_mock_data() parameters: config_path: Path CSV file listing variables generate details_path: Path CSV file specifying variable structure (categories, ranges, proportions) n: Number observations (rows) generate seed: Random seed reproducibility - seed always produces identical data verbose: Set FALSE suppress informational messages generation (useful cleaner output reports) validate: Optional, defaults TRUE - validates metadata generation happened: MockData read files understand variable structure Generated 100 random values {1, 2, 3} uniform distribution Returned data frame one column: smoking
code: # create_mock_data() reads CSV files, so we need to save our data.frames first temp_config <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") temp_details <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") write.csv(config, temp_config, row.names = FALSE) write.csv(details, temp_details, row.names = FALSE)  # Generate 100 observations mock_data <- create_mock_data(   config_path = temp_config,    # Path to configuration CSV   details_path = temp_details,  # Path to variable details CSV   n = 100,                      # Number of observations to generate   seed = 123,                   # Random seed for reproducibility   verbose = FALSE               # Suppress progress messages )  # Clean up temp files unlink(c(temp_config, temp_details))  # View the data head(mock_data, 10) smoking 1        2 2        1 3        3 4        1 5        1 6        2 7        3 8        1 9        3 10       3 table(mock_data$smoking) 1  2  3 33 33 34

title: Generating datasets from configuration files
text: Research papers typically include “Table 1” descriptive statistics. MockData lets generate data matches published statistics. Example scenario: paper reports smoking prevalence cohort: Daily smokers: 28% Occasional smokers: 18% Never smokers: 54% Let’s generate mock data matches proportions: Key insight: Proportions must sum 1.0 variable. MockData samples according proportions, making easy match published descriptive statistics.
code: # Add proportion column to match published statistics details_with_props <- data.frame(   uid = c("smoking_v1", "smoking_v1", "smoking_v1"),   uid_detail = c("smoking_v1_d1", "smoking_v1_d2", "smoking_v1_d3"),   variable = c("smoking", "smoking", "smoking"),   recStart = c("1", "2", "3"),   recEnd = c("1", "2", "3"),   catLabel = c("Daily smoker", "Occasional smoker", "Never smoked"),   catLabelLong = c("Smokes daily", "Smokes occasionally", "Never smoked"),   proportion = c(0.28, 0.18, 0.54),  # Match published prevalence   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Save to temporary files temp_config <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") temp_details <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") write.csv(config, temp_config, row.names = FALSE) write.csv(details_with_props, temp_details, row.names = FALSE)  # Generate data matching these proportions mock_data_table1 <- create_mock_data(   config_path = temp_config,   details_path = temp_details,   n = 1000,  # Larger sample for better proportion match   seed = 123,   verbose = FALSE )  # Clean up unlink(c(temp_config, temp_details))  # Verify proportions prop.table(table(mock_data_table1$smoking)) 1     2     3 0.286 0.169 0.545

title: Generating datasets from configuration files
text: Now let’s expand config include age alongside smoking: Multi-variable configuration (2 rows): Combined details table (5 rows): Note: Added rType column specify output types (factor smoking, integer age). happened: MockData generated 2 variables one call smoking: Factor 3 levels, distributed according proportions age: Integer values 18-100, 5% missing (code 999) variables respect specified rType Smoking distribution: Age summary: Data types: Smoking: factor Age: integer Missing values: Smoking: 0 / 1000 Age: 50 / 1000 Expected results: Smoking: ~28% daily, ~18% occasional, ~54% never (close specified proportions) Age: Integer values 18-100, approximately 5% coded 999 Smoking factor, age integer
code: # Add age to config config_multi <- data.frame(   uid = c("smoking_v1", "age_v1"),   variable = c("smoking", "age"),   role = c("enabled", "enabled"),   variableType = c("categorical", "continuous"),   variableLabel = c("Smoking status", "Age in years"),   position = c(1, 2),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE ) # Add age details (range + missing code) # Build smoking details first smoking_details <- data.frame(   uid = rep("smoking_v1", 3),   uid_detail = c("smoking_v1_d1", "smoking_v1_d2", "smoking_v1_d3"),   variable = rep("smoking", 3),   recStart = c("1", "2", "3"),   recEnd = c("1", "2", "3"),   catLabel = c("Daily smoker", "Occasional smoker", "Never smoked"),   catLabelLong = c("Smokes daily", "Smokes occasionally", "Never smoked"),   proportion = c(0.28, 0.18, 0.54),   rType = rep("factor", 3),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Build age details age_details <- data.frame(   uid = rep("age_v1", 2),   uid_detail = c("age_v1_d1", "age_v1_d2"),   variable = rep("age", 2),   recStart = c("[18, 100]", "999"),   recEnd = c("copy", "999"),   catLabel = c("Age in years", "Missing"),   catLabelLong = c("Age in years", "Not stated"),   proportion = c(0.95, 0.05),   rType = rep("integer", 2),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Combine details_multi <- rbind(smoking_details, age_details) # Save to temporary files temp_config <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") temp_details <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") write.csv(config_multi, temp_config, row.names = FALSE) write.csv(details_multi, temp_details, row.names = FALSE)  # Generate 1000 observations mock_data_multi <- create_mock_data(   config_path = temp_config,   details_path = temp_details,   n = 1000,   seed = 123,   verbose = FALSE )  # Clean up unlink(c(temp_config, temp_details))  # View first 10 rows head(mock_data_multi, 10) smoking age 1        3  40 2        1  67 3        3  31 4        2  88 5        2  88 6        3  57 7        3  81 8        2  42 9        1  23 10       3  54

code: # Add age to config config_multi <- data.frame(   uid = c("smoking_v1", "age_v1"),   variable = c("smoking", "age"),   role = c("enabled", "enabled"),   variableType = c("categorical", "continuous"),   variableLabel = c("Smoking status", "Age in years"),   position = c(1, 2),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )

title: Generating datasets from configuration files
text: Combined details table (5 rows): Note: Added rType column specify output types (factor smoking, integer age).
code: # Add age details (range + missing code) # Build smoking details first smoking_details <- data.frame(   uid = rep("smoking_v1", 3),   uid_detail = c("smoking_v1_d1", "smoking_v1_d2", "smoking_v1_d3"),   variable = rep("smoking", 3),   recStart = c("1", "2", "3"),   recEnd = c("1", "2", "3"),   catLabel = c("Daily smoker", "Occasional smoker", "Never smoked"),   catLabelLong = c("Smokes daily", "Smokes occasionally", "Never smoked"),   proportion = c(0.28, 0.18, 0.54),   rType = rep("factor", 3),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Build age details age_details <- data.frame(   uid = rep("age_v1", 2),   uid_detail = c("age_v1_d1", "age_v1_d2"),   variable = rep("age", 2),   recStart = c("[18, 100]", "999"),   recEnd = c("copy", "999"),   catLabel = c("Age in years", "Missing"),   catLabelLong = c("Age in years", "Not stated"),   proportion = c(0.95, 0.05),   rType = rep("integer", 2),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Combine details_multi <- rbind(smoking_details, age_details)

code: # Save to temporary files temp_config <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") temp_details <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") write.csv(config_multi, temp_config, row.names = FALSE) write.csv(details_multi, temp_details, row.names = FALSE)  # Generate 1000 observations mock_data_multi <- create_mock_data(   config_path = temp_config,   details_path = temp_details,   n = 1000,   seed = 123,   verbose = FALSE )  # Clean up unlink(c(temp_config, temp_details))  # View first 10 rows head(mock_data_multi, 10) smoking age 1        3  40 2        1  67 3        3  31 4        2  88 5        2  88 6        3  57 7        3  81 8        2  42 9        1  23 10       3  54

title: Generating datasets from configuration files
text: Smoking distribution: Age summary: Data types: Smoking: factor Age: integer Missing values: Smoking: 0 / 1000 Age: 50 / 1000 Expected results: Smoking: ~28% daily, ~18% occasional, ~54% never (close specified proportions) Age: Integer values 18-100, approximately 5% coded 999 Smoking factor, age integer

title: Generating datasets from configuration files
text: Date variables follow special pattern compatibility recodeflow metadata: variableType = "continuous" (dates stored numbers recodeflow) role contains “date” (e.g., “index-date”, “baseline-date”) rType = "Date" details (specifies R Date class) Let’s add birth date variable dataset: happened: MockData detected date variable checking role “date” Generated random dates 1950-01-01 2000-12-31 Applied rType = "Date" return R Date objects (numbers) Verification: Columns: smoking, age Note: birth_date column found output Key insight: pattern maintains compatibility recodeflow (dates variableType = "continuous") allowing MockData generate proper Date objects using rType.
code: # Add birth_date to config config_with_date <- rbind(   config_multi,   data.frame(     uid = "birth_date_v1",     variable = "birth_date",     role = "baseline-date",  # Role identifies this as a date     variableType = "continuous",  # Dates are continuous in recodeflow     variableLabel = "Date of birth",     position = 3,     stringsAsFactors = FALSE   ) )  # Build date details date_details <- data.frame(   uid = rep("birth_date_v1", 1),   uid_detail = c("birth_date_v1_d1"),   variable = rep("birth_date", 1),   recStart = c("[1950-01-01, 2000-12-31]"),  # Date range   recEnd = c("copy"),   catLabel = c("Birth date"),   catLabelLong = c("Date of birth"),   proportion = c(1.0),   rType = rep("Date", 1),  # Output as R Date class   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Combine all details details_with_date <- rbind(details_multi, date_details)  # Save and generate temp_config <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") temp_details <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") write.csv(config_with_date, temp_config, row.names = FALSE) write.csv(details_with_date, temp_details, row.names = FALSE)  mock_data_with_date <- create_mock_data(   config_path = temp_config,   details_path = temp_details,   n = 100,   seed = 123,   verbose = FALSE )  unlink(c(temp_config, temp_details))  # View results head(mock_data_with_date, 10) smoking age 1        3  67 2        1  45 3        3  58 4        2  96 5        2  58 6        3  91 7        3  93 8        2  68 9        1  52 10       3  30

title: Generating datasets from configuration files
text: Real datasets garbage values (data entry errors, --range values). MockData can simulate testing data validation pipelines. Garbage data summary: Garbage values found: 19 / 1000 Example garbage ages: 259, 257, 261, 244, 296 happened: Added corrupt_high specification range [200, 300] MockData adjusted proportions rows sum 1.0 Generated ~2% garbage values testing data cleaning pipelines Common garbage types: corrupt_low: Values valid range corrupt_high: Values valid range corrupt_future: Dates future (date variables) corrupt_past: Dates far past (date variables) See Garbage data documentation complete specifications.
code: # Add garbage rows to details details_with_garbage <- rbind(   details_multi,   data.frame(     uid = "age_v1",     uid_detail = "age_v1_d3",     variable = "age",     recStart = "[200, 300]",     recEnd = "corrupt_high",     catLabel = "Data entry error",     catLabelLong = "Impossible age value",     proportion = 0.02,     rType = "integer",     stringsAsFactors = FALSE   ) )  # Note: proportions will be automatically normalized to sum to 1.0  # Save to temporary files temp_config <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") temp_details <- tempfile(fileext = ".csv") write.csv(config_multi, temp_config, row.names = FALSE) write.csv(details_with_garbage, temp_details, row.names = FALSE)  # Regenerate with garbage mock_data_dirty <- create_mock_data(   config_path = temp_config,   details_path = temp_details,   n = 1000,   seed = 123,   verbose = FALSE )  # Clean up unlink(c(temp_config, temp_details))  # Find garbage values garbage_count <- sum(mock_data_dirty$age > 100 & mock_data_dirty$age < 999, na.rm = TRUE) example_garbage <- head(mock_data_dirty$age[mock_data_dirty$age > 100 & mock_data_dirty$age < 999], 5)

title: Generating datasets from configuration files
text: real projects, ’ll reuse existing harmonization metadata. MockData works files used recodeflow: DemPoRT variables (first 10): ADL_01, ADL_02, ADL_03, ADL_04, ADL_05, ADL_06, ADL_07, ADL_der, ADL_score_5, ADL_score_6 Total variables: 74 Details rows: 669 Key insight: metadata files used harmonization. reusing mock data generation, ensure consistency mock real data structures. Typical workflow: Define variables harmonization rules recodeflow Use metadata generate mock data testing Develop analysis pipelines mock data Apply real data pipelines validated
code: # Load DemPoRT example configuration (from recodeflow) config_file <- system.file(   "extdata/demport/variables_DemPoRT.csv",   package = "MockData" ) details_file <- system.file(   "extdata/demport/variable_details_DemPoRT.csv",   package = "MockData" )  # Read configuration demport_config <- read.csv(config_file, stringsAsFactors = FALSE, check.names = FALSE) demport_details <- read.csv(details_file, stringsAsFactors = FALSE, check.names = FALSE)  # See what variables are available first_10_vars <- head(demport_config$variable, 10) n_vars <- nrow(demport_config) n_details <- nrow(demport_details)

title: Working with date variables
text: tutorial introduces temporal data generation MockData. ’ll learn create date variables : Cohort entry dates (index dates, baseline dates) Event dates (death, diagnosis, hospital admission) Time-varying exposures (follow-visits, repeated measures) Survival analysis data (censoring) complete working examples: See DemPoRT example, primary comprehensive demonstration date variable generation real ICES specifications.

title: Working with date variables
text: Date variables use two-file structure variables, special recEnd codes: mock_data_config.csv: mock_data_config_details.csv: Key points: Use recEnd = "date_start" mark row containing start date Use recEnd = "date_end" mark row containing end date Dates date_start date_end columns use ISO format: YYYY-MM-DD Date variables need rType = "Date" details Date variables use role containing “date” (e.g., “index-date”, “outcome-date”) variableType = "Continuous" date variables (recodeflow compatibility) Result: 100 dates uniformly distributed 2001-01-01 2017-03-31.
code: library(dplyr) library(MockData)  # Create configuration config <- data.frame(   uid = "index_date_v1",   variable = "index_date",   role = "index-date,enabled",   variableType = "Continuous",   position = 1,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  details <- data.frame(   uid = c("index_date_v1", "index_date_v1"),   uid_detail = c("index_date_v1_d1", "index_date_v1_d2"),   variable = c("index_date", "index_date"),   recStart = c(NA, NA),   recEnd = c("date_start", "date_end"),   catLabel = c("Start date", "End date"),   date_start = c("2001-01-01", NA),   date_end = c(NA, "2017-03-31"),   rType = c("Date", "Date"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Write to temporary files temp_dir <- tempdir() config_path <- file.path(temp_dir, "date_config.csv") details_path <- file.path(temp_dir, "date_details.csv") write.csv(config, config_path, row.names = FALSE) write.csv(details, details_path, row.names = FALSE)  # Generate dates mock_data <- create_mock_data(   config_path = config_path,   details_path = details_path,   n = 100,   seed = 123 )  # View distribution head(mock_data) index_date 1 2007-09-29 2 2007-11-16 3 2007-02-05 4 2002-06-10 5 2012-09-30 6 2009-03-05 summary(mock_data$index_date) Min.      1st Qu.       Median         Mean      3rd Qu.         Max. "2001-02-10" "2004-12-02" "2008-02-23" "2008-08-21" "2012-08-10" "2016-10-17"

text: Result: 100 dates uniformly distributed 2001-01-01 2017-03-31.

Write to temporary files temp_dir <- tempdir() config_path <- file.path(temp_dir, "missing_events_config.csv") details_path <- file.path(temp_dir, "missing_events_details.csv") write.csv(config, config_path, row.names = FALSE) write.csv(details, details_path, row.names = FALSE)  # Generate mock_data <- create_mock_data(   config_path = config_path,   details_path = details_path,   n = 100,   seed = 123 )  # Set death_date to NA for non-deaths mock_data$death_date[mock_data$death_occurred == 0] <- NA  # Check result table(is.na(mock_data$death_date))  # Should be ~70% NA

title: Working with date variables
text: MockData generates dates uniformly across range: Use cases: Cohort accrual constant enrollment Administrative dates without seasonal patterns General-purpose test data MockData currently supports uniform date distributions. non-uniform patterns: Option 1: Generate uniform, transform Option 2: Use DemPoRT patterns DemPoRT example demonstrates realistic temporal patterns cohort studies, including: Staggered accrual periods Age-dependent event rates Administrative censoring Loss follow-patterns
code: # All dates equally likely between start and end # Generate uniform dates mock_data <- create_mock_data(config, details, n = 1000, seed = 123)  # Transform to exponential distribution (early enrollment peak) date_range <- as.numeric(difftime(   max(mock_data$index_date),   min(mock_data$index_date),   units = "days" ))  # Convert to exponential (more early dates) # This is a post-processing transformation uniform_props <- (mock_data$index_date - min(mock_data$index_date)) / date_range exp_props <- 1 - exp(-2 * as.numeric(uniform_props))  # Shape parameter = 2  mock_data$index_date_exp <- min(mock_data$index_date) +   round(exp_props * date_range)

text: generating dates, calculate common derived variables:
code: # Assuming you have birth_date and index_date mock_data$age_at_index <- as.numeric(   difftime(mock_data$index_date, mock_data$birth_date, units = "days") ) / 365.25  # Or using lubridate library(lubridate) mock_data$age_at_index <- time_length(   interval(mock_data$birth_date, mock_data$index_date),   "years" ) # Time from index to event/censoring mock_data$followup_years <- as.numeric(   difftime(mock_data$death_date, mock_data$index_date, units = "days") ) / 365.25 # Extract year for period analysis mock_data$index_year <- as.numeric(format(mock_data$index_date, "%Y"))  # Fiscal year (Canada: April 1 - March 31) mock_data$fiscal_year <- ifelse(   as.numeric(format(mock_data$index_date, "%m")) >= 4,   as.numeric(format(mock_data$index_date, "%Y")),   as.numeric(format(mock_data$index_date, "%Y")) - 1 ) # Event occurred within study period study_end <- as.Date("2020-12-31") mock_data$event <- ifelse(   mock_data$death_date <= study_end,   1,  # Event occurred   0   # Censored )  # Time to event or censoring mock_data$time <- pmin(   as.numeric(difftime(mock_data$death_date, mock_data$index_date, units = "days")),   as.numeric(difftime(study_end, mock_data$index_date, units = "days")) )

title: Working with date variables
text: Generate anchor date first, calculate dependent dates: Match date ranges study design: Cohort studies: Accrual period + follow-period Cross-sectional surveys: Survey fielding period Administrative data: Reporting period Add notes configuration: generation, check:
code: # Generate baseline date with MockData baseline_config <- data.frame(   uid = "baseline_date_v1",   variable = "baseline_date",   role = "index-date,enabled",   variableType = "Continuous",   position = 1,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  baseline_details <- data.frame(   uid = c("baseline_date_v1", "baseline_date_v1"),   uid_detail = c("baseline_date_v1_d1", "baseline_date_v1_d2"),   variable = c("baseline_date", "baseline_date"),   recStart = c(NA, NA),   recEnd = c("date_start", "date_end"),   catLabel = c("Start", "End"),   date_start = c("2010-01-01", NA),   date_end = c(NA, "2015-12-31"),   rType = c("Date", "Date"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Write to temporary files temp_dir <- tempdir() config_path <- file.path(temp_dir, "baseline_config.csv") details_path <- file.path(temp_dir, "baseline_details.csv") write.csv(baseline_config, config_path, row.names = FALSE) write.csv(baseline_details, details_path, row.names = FALSE)  # Generate baseline dates mock_data <- create_mock_data(   config_path = config_path,   details_path = details_path,   n = 100,   seed = 123 )  # Calculate dependent dates mock_data$followup_date <- mock_data$baseline_date + 365  # +1 year mock_data$death_date <- mock_data$baseline_date +   sample(365:3650, 100, replace = TRUE)  # Random 1-10 years # No negative follow-up times stopifnot(all(mock_data$death_date >= mock_data$index_date, na.rm = TRUE))  # Events within expected range study_start <- as.Date("2001-01-01") study_end <- as.Date("2025-12-31") stopifnot(all(mock_data$death_date >= study_start, na.rm = TRUE)) stopifnot(all(mock_data$death_date <= study_end, na.rm = TRUE))

title: Generating garbage data for validation testing
text: Data validation critical research quality, know validation rules actually work? best approach generate mock data known quality issues, run validation pipeline, verify catches exactly expect. tutorial focuses DemPoRT project’s validation needs. DemPoRT analysts receive large administrative datasets need robust validation pipelines catch data quality issues analysis. generating mock data intentional errors, can: Test validation logic applying real data Document expected error rates different quality checks Train new team members common data quality patterns Benchmark validation performance known error proportions Let’s start motivating example. Suppose ’re validating alcohol consumption coding health survey dataset: clean data generated metadata, validation check finds 0 invalid codes. validation logic actually work? Let’s add intentional garbage using prop_invalid parameter: Now validation finds 30 invalid codes (3% records). matches expected 3% garbage proportion, confirming validation logic works correctly. pattern—generate garbage, run validation, verify detection—foundation robust data quality testing.
code: # Load CCHS metadata variable_details <- read.csv(   system.file("extdata/cchs/variable_details_cchsflow_sample.csv",               package = "MockData"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  variables <- read.csv(   system.file("extdata/cchs/variables_cchsflow_sample.csv",               package = "MockData"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Generate alcohol variable WITHOUT garbage (clean data only) df_clean <- data.frame() alc_clean <- create_cat_var(   var_raw = "ALC_1",   cycle = "cchs2001_p",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 1000,   df_mock = df_clean,   seed = 123 )  # Check for invalid codes (valid codes are 1, 2, and 6 for valid skip) valid_codes <- c("1", "2", "6") invalid_clean <- sum(!alc_clean$ALC_1 %in% valid_codes) # Generate alcohol variable WITH garbage using prop_invalid parameter df_garbage <- data.frame() alc_garbage <- create_cat_var(   var_raw = "ALC_1",   cycle = "cchs2001_p",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 1000,   df_mock = df_garbage,   prop_invalid = 0.03,  # 3% invalid codes   seed = 456 )  # Run validation check invalid_garbage <- sum(!alc_garbage$ALC_1 %in% valid_codes) invalid_rate <- invalid_garbage / nrow(alc_garbage)

title: Generating garbage data for validation testing
text: Categorical variables can several types garbage data. common : Invalid codes: Values aren’t valid category set. Examples: “.”, “NA”, “missing”, numeric codes outside defined range. Type mismatches: Wrong data types. Example: Numeric codes stored floats (1.0 instead 1). Encoding issues: Character encoding problems. Example: “Montr0e9al” becomes “Montr”. MockData uses prop_invalid parameter automatically generate invalid category codes testing validation logic. Let’s generate ADL (Activities Daily Living) variable 3% garbage. prop_invalid parameter tells MockData generate random invalid codes found metadata: Validation results: Total records: 2000 Invalid codes found: 60 (3%) Garbage codes detected: -1, -9, -99, 88, 888, 96, 97, 98, 99, 999, 9999 matches expected 3% garbage rate, confirming validation logic correctly identifies invalid codes generated prop_invalid.
code: # Generate ADL variable with 3% invalid codes df_adl <- data.frame() adl_garbage <- create_cat_var(   var_raw = "ADL_01",   cycle = "cchs2001_p",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 2000,   df_mock = df_adl,   prop_invalid = 0.03,  # 3% invalid codes   seed = 789 )  # Validation: check for invalid codes # Get valid codes from metadata for ADL_01 adl_details <- variable_details[variable_details$variable == "ADL_01" &                                 grepl("cchs2001_p", variable_details$databaseStart, fixed = TRUE), ] valid_adl_codes <- unique(adl_details$recEnd[!is.na(adl_details$recEnd)])  # Check for codes not in metadata invalid_adl <- !adl_garbage$ADL_01 %in% valid_adl_codes n_invalid <- sum(invalid_adl) invalid_pct <- round(n_invalid / nrow(adl_garbage) * 100, 1)

code: # Generate ADL variable with 3% invalid codes df_adl <- data.frame() adl_garbage <- create_cat_var(   var_raw = "ADL_01",   cycle = "cchs2001_p",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 2000,   df_mock = df_adl,   prop_invalid = 0.03,  # 3% invalid codes   seed = 789 )  # Validation: check for invalid codes # Get valid codes from metadata for ADL_01 adl_details <- variable_details[variable_details$variable == "ADL_01" &                                 grepl("cchs2001_p", variable_details$databaseStart, fixed = TRUE), ] valid_adl_codes <- unique(adl_details$recEnd[!is.na(adl_details$recEnd)])  # Check for codes not in metadata invalid_adl <- !adl_garbage$ADL_01 %in% valid_adl_codes n_invalid <- sum(invalid_adl) invalid_pct <- round(n_invalid / nrow(adl_garbage) * 100, 1)

title: Generating garbage data for validation testing
text: Continuous variables different garbage patterns categorical variables. Common issues include: --range values: Numbers outside biologically/logically plausible ranges. Example: Age = 250 years. Type corruption: Values stored wrong type. Example: Age stored character “45.5” instead numeric. Precision issues: Inappropriate decimal places. Example: Age = 45.7829 (overly precise). MockData uses special recEnd codes generate continuous garbage: corrupt_high: Values valid range corrupt_low: Values valid range corrupt_na: Missing value indicators stored numbers (e.g., -999) Let’s generate alcohol consumption data (number drinks Sunday) --range garbage. valid range 0-50 drinks, ’ll use prop_invalid generate values outside range: Validation results: Total records: 2000 --range values: 20 (1%) Overall range: 0 148.7 drinks Garbage range: 51.2 148.7 confirms validator correctly identifies --range drink values. prop_invalid parameter generates values maximum (50 drinks) variable. can test validation thresholds generating data different garbage rates. Let’s create drinks data 5% invalid values check validator handles higher garbage rates: validator detects: Excessive drinks (>50): 50 (2.5%) Maximum excessive: 149.8 higher garbage rate (5%), validators detect invalid values, allowing test validation pipeline handles varying levels data quality issues.
code: # Generate drinks data with 2% out-of-range garbage df_drinks <- data.frame() drinks_garbage <- create_con_var(   var_raw = "ALW_2A1",   cycle = "cchs2001_p",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 2000,   df_mock = df_drinks,   prop_invalid = 0.02,  # 2% out-of-range values   seed = 200 )  # Validate: check for out-of-range values # Valid range for ALW_2A1 is [0, 50] out_of_range <- drinks_garbage$ALW_2A1 < 0 | drinks_garbage$ALW_2A1 > 50 n_invalid <- sum(out_of_range, na.rm = TRUE) invalid_pct <- round(n_invalid / nrow(drinks_garbage) * 100, 1) # Generate drinks data with higher garbage rate df_drinks2 <- data.frame() drinks_garbage2 <- create_con_var(   var_raw = "ALW_2A1",   cycle = "cchs2001_p",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 2000,   df_mock = df_drinks2,   prop_invalid = 0.05,  # 5% out-of-range values   seed = 201 )  # Validate: check for out-of-range values excessive_drinks <- drinks_garbage2$ALW_2A1 > 50 n_excessive <- sum(excessive_drinks, na.rm = TRUE)
