text: Date variables can also use prop_invalid parameter generate dates outside specified ranges. date variables, prop_invalid generates dates 1-5 years valid range, making clearly invalid validation testing. date garbage generation works way continuous variables—specify proportion invalid values function automatically generates --range dates testing validators.

title: Generating garbage data for validation testing
text: Survival analysis requires coordinated date validation across multiple time points. Garbage data helps test complex validation rules temporal consistency. Common survival data quality issues: Date sequence violations: Death birth, death interview Impossible survival times: Negative follow-time, follow-exceeding study period Censoring inconsistencies: Status indicates death death date recorded survival data, create_survival_dates() supports prop_invalid parameter generate temporal violations (entry date > event date): Validation detects 60 temporal violations (3%), matching 3% garbage specification. prop_invalid specified, create_survival_dates() swaps entry event dates specified proportion records, creating realistic temporal violations validator testing. Temporal violations also produce invalid derived variables like negative follow-time: Validation results derived variables: Negative follow-time: 60 (3%) negative follow-times correspond exactly temporal violations, confirming validators catch derived quality issues.
code: # Generate survival dates with 3% temporal violations survival_dates <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var = "study_entry",   event_var = "death_date",   entry_start = as.Date("2015-01-01"),   entry_end = as.Date("2016-12-31"),   followup_min = 30,      # Minimum 30 days   followup_max = 3650,    # Maximum 10 years   length = 2000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   prop_invalid = 0.03,    # 3% temporal violations   seed = 400 )  # Validate: entry should occur before event (death) temporal_violations <- survival_dates$study_entry > survival_dates$death_date n_violations <- sum(temporal_violations, na.rm = TRUE) # Calculate follow-up time in days (entry to event) survival_dates$followup_days <- as.numeric(   difftime(     survival_dates$death_date,     survival_dates$study_entry,     units = "days"   ) )  # Validate: follow-up should be non-negative negative_followup <- survival_dates$followup_days < 0 n_negative_fu <- sum(negative_followup, na.rm = TRUE)

title: Generating garbage data for validation testing
text: Now understand individual garbage patterns, let’s build complete validation pipeline tests quality checks systematically. ’ll use MockData functions generate dataset multiple garbage types: validation suite detects intentional garbage patterns. failure rates match specified proportions (3% ALC_1, 2% ALW_2A1), confirming validator works correctly.
code: # Generate complete dataset with multiple garbage types using MockData df_full <- data.frame()  # Step 1: Categorical variable with garbage (ALC_1) alc_full <- create_cat_var(   var_raw = "ALC_1",   cycle = "cchs2001_p",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 5000,   df_mock = df_full,   prop_invalid = 0.03,  # 3% invalid codes   seed = 500 )  # Step 2: Continuous variable with garbage (ALW_2A1) df_full <- alc_full drinks_full <- create_con_var(   var_raw = "ALW_2A1",   cycle = "cchs2001_p",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 5000,   df_mock = df_full,   prop_invalid = 0.02,  # 2% out-of-range   seed = 501 )  # Combine into single dataset full_data <- cbind(alc_full, drinks_full)  # Run validation suite # Check 1: Categorical codes alc_details <- variable_details[variable_details$variable == "ALC_1" &                                 grepl("cchs2001_p", variable_details$databaseStart, fixed = TRUE), ] valid_alc <- unique(alc_details$recEnd[!is.na(alc_details$recEnd)]) alc_invalid <- !full_data$ALC_1 %in% valid_alc  # Check 2: Drinks range (valid: 0-50) drinks_invalid <- full_data$ALW_2A1 < 0 | full_data$ALW_2A1 > 50  # Check 3: Combined validation (any record with any issue) any_issue <- alc_invalid | drinks_invalid  # Build results table validation_results <- data.frame(   check = c("ALC_1: invalid codes", "ALW_2A1: out of range", "Any validation failure"),   n_fail = c(sum(alc_invalid), sum(drinks_invalid, na.rm = TRUE), sum(any_issue, na.rm = TRUE)),   pct_fail = c(     round(sum(alc_invalid) / nrow(full_data) * 100, 2),     round(sum(drinks_invalid, na.rm = TRUE) / nrow(full_data) * 100, 2),     round(sum(any_issue, na.rm = TRUE) / nrow(full_data) * 100, 2)   ) )  # Display results validation_results check n_fail pct_fail 1   ALC_1: invalid codes    150     3.00 2  ALW_2A1: out of range     50     1.00 3 Any validation failure    199     3.98

what: Understanding missing data in health surveys
title: Missing data in health surveys
text: Health surveys use structured missing data codes distinguish different types non-response. Unlike general R data NA represents missing value, survey data differentiates several categories missingness. distinction crucial accurate statistical analysis. Consider simple example: calculating smoking prevalence survey data. treat missing values way, ’ll get biased estimates. Let’s see . Now let’s calculate prevalence ways: naive approach gives us prevalence 22.4%, correct approach gives 22%. difference matters making population-level estimates comparing across surveys. health surveys, missing values mean thing. Canadian Community Health Survey (CCHS) Canadian Health Measures Survey (CHMS) use standardized system missing data codes: Valid skip (996): question asked skip logic determined wasn’t applicable Don’t know (997): question asked respondent didn’t know answer Refusal (998): question asked respondent refused answer stated (999): question asked response recorded type different statistical implications. Valid skips excluded denominator (weren’t part eligible population question). don’t know, refusal, stated included denominator calculating response rates, even though ’re excluded numerator calculating prevalence. Let’s generate realistic data see action: Health surveys categorize missing data three main types, requiring different statistical treatment. Valid skip (code 996) valid skip occurs skip logic determines question asked. example, someone reports ’ve never smoked, won’t asked “many cigarettes per day smoke?” isn’t truly missing data—’s logical consequence previous answer. Statistical treatment: Exclude numerator denominator. respondents weren’t eligible question. Don’t know / Refusal / stated (codes 997, 998, 999) codes represent questions asked didn’t receive valid responses: 997 (Don’t know): Respondent uncertain answer 998 (Refusal): Respondent declined answer 999 (stated): Question asked response recorded Statistical treatment: Include denominator calculating response rates (eligible asked), exclude numerator calculating prevalence (don’t know true status). applicable (code 996, sometimes labeled NA::) similar valid skip—question doesn’t apply respondent’s situation. statistical treatment valid skip. Let’s demonstrate difference worked example: dataset: Sample size: respondents Valid skip: 0 (asked due skip logic) Asked: 0 (eligible question) Response rate: NaN% (valid responses ÷ asked) Smoking prevalence: NaN% (current smokers ÷ asked excluding DK/NS) Notice valid skip (6) doesn’t factor either calculation—respondents never part eligible population question. Let’s use actual CCHS metadata generate realistic missing data patterns. CCHS uses coding schemes across hundreds variables. shows missing codes appear actual survey metadata. recEnd column contains category values, including substantive responses (1-4 frequency categories) missing data codes (6, 7, 9, 96, 97, 99). can use metadata generate mock data realistic proportions: alcohol consumption variable: Response rate: NaN% (0 valid responses ÷ 0 asked) Regular drinking prevalence: NaN% (0 regular drinkers ÷ 0 asked) Don’t know responses: 0 (NaN% asked) stated: 0 (NaN% asked) demonstrates real CCHS data includes measurable proportions missing data codes, distinguishing matters accurate statistical reporting.
code: # Generate smoking data with two approaches set.seed(123)  # Wrong approach: treating all missing as NA smoking_wrong <- data.frame(   smoker = sample(c("Yes", "No", NA), 1000,                   replace = TRUE,                   prob = c(0.20, 0.70, 0.10)) )  # Correct approach: using survey missing codes smoking_correct <- data.frame(   smoker = sample(c("1", "2", "6", "7", "9"), 1000,                   replace = TRUE,                   prob = c(0.20, 0.70, 0.05, 0.03, 0.02)) ) # Wrong calculation (naive approach) wrong_prevalence <- mean(smoking_wrong$smoker == "Yes", na.rm = TRUE)  # Correct calculation (excluding valid skip, including DK/RF/NS in denominator) valid_responses <- smoking_correct$smoker %in% c("1", "2", "7", "9") correct_prevalence <- sum(smoking_correct$smoker == "1") / sum(valid_responses) # Load metadata for examples variable_details <- read.csv(   system.file("extdata/cchs/variable_details_cchsflow_sample.csv",               package = "MockData"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  variables <- read.csv(   system.file("extdata/cchs/variables_cchsflow_sample.csv",               package = "MockData"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Create smoking data with realistic proportions using MockData df_mock <- data.frame() smoking_data <- create_cat_var(   var_raw = "SMK_01",   cycle = "cchs2015_2016_p",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 1000,   df_mock = df_mock,   proportions = list(     "1" = 0.18,  # Current smoker     "2" = 0.65,  # Never smoked     "3" = 0.12,  # Former smoker     "6" = 0.01,  # Valid skip     "7" = 0.02,  # Don't know     "9" = 0.02   # Not stated   ),   seed = 456 )  # Show distribution table(smoking_data$SMK_01) < table of extent 0 > # Calculate response rate (includes DK/RF/NS in denominator) asked <- smoking_data$SMK_01 %in% c("1", "2", "3", "7", "9") valid_response <- smoking_data$SMK_01 %in% c("1", "2", "3") response_rate <- sum(valid_response) / sum(asked)  # Calculate prevalence (excludes valid skip from denominator, excludes DK/NS from numerator) current_smoker <- smoking_data$SMK_01 == "1" asked_not_skip <- smoking_data$SMK_01 %in% c("1", "2", "3", "7", "9") prevalence <- sum(current_smoker) / sum(asked_not_skip) # Load CCHS metadata variable_details <- read.csv(   system.file("extdata/cchs/variable_details_cchsflow_sample.csv",               package = "MockData"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Look at alcohol consumption variable alc_details <- variable_details[variable_details$variable == "ALC_15", ] head(alc_details[, c("variable", "recEnd", "catLabel", "catLabelLong")], 10) [1] variable     recEnd       catLabel     catLabelLong <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names) # Generate alcohol consumption data using CCHS patterns df_mock_alc <- data.frame() alcohol_data <- create_cat_var(   var_raw = "ALC_15",   cycle = "cchs2015_2016_p",   variable_details = variable_details,   variables = variables,   length = 2000,   df_mock = df_mock_alc,   proportions = list(     "1" = 0.15,   # Regular drinker     "2" = 0.35,   # Occasional drinker     "3" = 0.28,   # Infrequent drinker     "4" = 0.15,   # Non-drinker     "6" = 0.01,   # Valid skip     "7" = 0.03,   # Don't know     "9" = 0.03    # Not stated   ),   seed = 789 )  # Calculate response rate and prevalence of regular drinking asked_alc <- alcohol_data$ALC_15 %in% c("1", "2", "3", "4", "7", "9") valid_alc <- alcohol_data$ALC_15 %in% c("1", "2", "3", "4") response_rate_alc <- sum(valid_alc) / sum(asked_alc)  regular_drinker <- alcohol_data$ALC_15 == "1" prevalence_alc <- sum(regular_drinker) / sum(asked_alc)

title: Generate Mock Data from Recodeflow Metadata
text: package, “mock data” refers metadata-driven simulated data created solely software testing workflow validation. Mock data generated variable specifications (e.g., variables.csv, variable_details.csv) contain real person-level data identifiable information. Key distinctions: Mock data (package): Generated metadata . Mimics variable structure ranges real-world statistical relationships. Used testing pipelines, analysis. Synthetic data: Preserves statistical properties relationships real datasets generative models. May used research properly validated. Dummy data: Placeholder minimal test data, often hardcoded randomly generated without metadata constraints. MockData creates data looks realistic (appropriate variable types, value ranges, category labels, tagged NAs) relationship actual population. Joint distributions correlations may differ significantly real-world data.

title: Generate Mock Data from Recodeflow Metadata
text: Note: steps generate mock data development testing —modelling analysis. Data created reproducible seeds consistent test results.
code: library(MockData)  # Load metadata (CHMS example with sample data) variables <- read.csv(   system.file("extdata/chms/variables_chmsflow_sample.csv", package = "MockData"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE ) variable_details <- read.csv(   system.file("extdata/chms/variable_details_chmsflow_sample.csv", package = "MockData"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Get variables for a specific cycle cycle1_vars <- get_cycle_variables("cycle1", variables, variable_details)  # Get unique raw variables to generate raw_vars <- get_raw_variables("cycle1", variables, variable_details)  # Create empty data frame df_mock <- data.frame(id = 1:1000)  # Generate a categorical variable result <- create_cat_var("alc_11", "cycle1", variable_details, variables,                         length = 1000, df_mock = df_mock, seed = 123) if (!is.null(result)) {   df_mock <- cbind(df_mock, result) }  # Generate a continuous variable result <- create_con_var("alcdwky", "cycle1", variable_details, variables,                         length = 1000, df_mock = df_mock, seed = 123) if (!is.null(result)) {   df_mock <- cbind(df_mock, result) }

title: Create categorical variable for MockData — create_cat_var
text: function determines proportions priority order: Explicit proportions parameter (provided) proportion column variable_details (present) Uniform distribution (default fallback) Uses determine_proportions() helper handle proportion logic cleanly. Generates values using vectorized sample() efficiency. Type coercion (rType): metadata contains rType column, values coerced specified R type: "factor": Converts factor levels category codes (default categorical) "character": Converts character vector "integer": Converts integer (numeric category codes) "logical": Converts logical (TRUE/FALSE categories) types passed without coercion allows categorical variables returned factors proper levels, types appropriate data. rType specified, defaults character.

what: Create mock data from configuration files — create_mock_data
title: Create mock data from configuration files — create_mock_data
text: Main orchestrator function generates complete mock datasets v0.2 configuration files. Reads config details files, filters enabled variables, dispatches type-specific create_* functions, assembles results complete data frame.

title: Create mock data from configuration files — create_mock_data

title: Create mock data from configuration files — create_mock_data
text: config_path Character. Path mock_data_config.csv file. details_path Character. Optional path mock_data_config_details.csv. NULL, uses uniform distributions (fallback mode). n Integer. Number observations generate (default 1000). seed Integer. Optional random seed reproducibility. source_format Character. Format simulate post-import data different sources. Options: "analysis" (default, R Date objects), "csv" (character strings), "sas" (numeric days since 1960-01-01). affects date variables. validate Logical. Whether validate configuration files (default TRUE). verbose Logical. Whether print progress messages (default FALSE).

title: Create mock data from configuration files — create_mock_data
text: Data frame n rows one column per enabled variable.

title: Create mock data from configuration files — create_mock_data
text: function performs following steps: Read validate config file Read validate details file (provided) Filter enabled variables Set global seed (provided) Loop variables position order: Extract var_row details_subset Dispatch create_cat_var, create_con_var, create_date_var, create_survival_dates Merge result data frame Return complete dataset Fallback mode: details_path = NULL, uses uniform distributions enabled variables. Variable types supported: categorical: create_cat_var() continuous: create_con_var() date: create_date_var() survival: create_survival_dates() character: create_char_var() (implemented) integer: create_int_var() (implemented)

Single row mock_data_config event date variable event_details_subset data.frame. Rows mock_data_config_details event date n integer. Number observations generate seed integer. Minimum follow-days followup_max integer. Maximum follow-days length integer. Number records generate event_distribution character. title: Create paired survival dates for cohort studies — create_survival_dates
text: Configuration v0.2 format (NEW): v0.2 format (NEW): Extracts date ranges entry_details_subset event_details_subset Generates entry dates uniformly distributed Calculates event dates ensure entry < event Supports garbage data via catLabel::garbage event_details_subset Supports fallback mode: reasonable defaults details_subset NULL v0.1 format (LEGACY): Accepts explicit date ranges follow-parameters Supports multiple event distributions (uniform, gompertz, exponential) Handles censoring, missing values, temporal violations via parameters function auto-detects format based parameter names. function generates realistic survival data : Creating entry dates uniformly distributed across entry period Generating follow-times using specified distribution Calculating event dates (entry + follow-) Optionally censoring events (event_status = 0) Ensuring entry_date < event_date records Event distributions: "uniform": Constant hazard follow-period "gompertz": Increasing hazard (mortality increases time) "exponential": Decreasing hazard (early events common) Censoring: prop_censored > 0, generates event_status column: 1 = event observed 0 = censored (event_date becomes censoring date)

title: Create paired survival dates for cohort studies — create_survival_dates
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # v0.2 format - called by create_mock_data() config <- read_mock_data_config("mock_data_config.csv") details <- read_mock_data_config_details("mock_data_config_details.csv") entry_row <- config[config$variable == "study_entry", ] entry_details <- get_variable_details(details, variable_name = "study_entry") event_row <- config[config$variable == "death_date", ] event_details <- get_variable_details(details, variable_name = "death_date") surv_data <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var_row = entry_row,   entry_details_subset = entry_details,   event_var_row = event_row,   event_details_subset = event_details,   n = 1000,   seed = 123 )  # v0.2 with garbage (catLabel::garbage in config_details) # In mock_data_config_details.csv: # variable,recEnd,catLabel,proportion # death_date,followup_min,, # death_date,followup_max,, # death_date,garbage,garbage,0.03 event_details_with_garbage <- get_variable_details(details, variable_name = "death_date") surv_data_garbage <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var_row = entry_row,   entry_details_subset = entry_details,   event_var_row = event_row,   event_details_subset = event_details_with_garbage,   n = 1000,   seed = 123 )  # v0.1 format (legacy) - Basic mortality study surv_data <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var = "study_entry",   event_var = "death_date",   entry_start = as.Date("2000-01-01"),   entry_end = as.Date("2005-12-31"),   followup_min = 365,   followup_max = 3650,   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   event_distribution = "gompertz" )  # v0.1 with censoring surv_data <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var = "cohort_entry",   event_var = "event_date",   entry_start = as.Date("2010-01-01"),   entry_end = as.Date("2015-12-31"),   followup_min = 30,   followup_max = 1825,   length = 500,   df_mock = data.frame(),   event_distribution = "exponential",   prop_censored = 0.3 )  # v0.1 with temporal violations for validation testing surv_data <- create_survival_dates(   entry_var = "interview_date",   event_var = "death_date",   entry_start = as.Date("2015-01-01"),   entry_end = as.Date("2016-12-31"),   followup_min = 30,   followup_max = 3650,   length = 1000,   df_mock = data.frame(),   prop_invalid = 0.03  # 3% temporal violations ) } # }

title: Parse range notation from variable_details — parse_range_notation
text: range_string Character string containing range notation range_type Character. One : "auto" (default): Auto-detect based bracket notation decimal values "integer": Force integer range interpretation (generates sequence) "continuous": Force continuous range interpretation expand_integers Logical. TRUE range_type "integer", returns integers range vector

title: Parse range notation from variable_details — parse_range_notation
text: continuous ranges: List min, max, min_inclusive, max_inclusive integer ranges: List min, max, values (expand_integers=TRUE) Returns NULL parsing fails

title: Parse range notation from variable_details — parse_range_notation
text: Recodeflow-Standard Range Notation: patterns work across recodeflow projects (CHMS, CCHS, etc.): Integer ranges: [7,9] → integers 7,8,9 Continuous ranges: [18.5,25) → 18.5 ≤ x < 25 Continuous ranges: [18.5,25] → 18.5 ≤ x ≤ 25 Infinity ranges: [30,inf) → x ≥ 30 Special codes: NA::, NA::b, copy, else (passed unchanged) Function calls: Func::function_name (passed unchanged) Mathematical Bracket Notation: [,b] - Closed interval: ≤ x ≤ b [,b) - Half-open interval: ≤ x < b (,b] - Half-open interval: < x ≤ b (,b) - Open interval: < x < b Auto-Detection Logic: Contains decimal values → continuous range Uses mathematical bracket notation [,b) → continuous range Simple [integer,integer] → integer range (generates sequence) Contains "inf" → continuous range [,b)` - Half-open interval: ≤ x < b `(,b]: R:,b)%60%20-%20Half-open%20interval:%20a%20%E2%89%A4%20x%20%3C%20b%0A-%20%60(,b [integer,integer]: R:integer,integer

title: Parse range notation from variable_details — parse_range_notation
text: Adapted cchsflow v4.0.0 (2025-07-27) - universal across recodeflow projects

title: Parse range notation from variable_details — parse_range_notation
code: # Integer ranges parse_range_notation("[7,9]") #> $type #> [1] "integer" #>  #> $min #> [1] 7 #>  #> $max #> [1] 9 #>  #> $values #> [1] 7 8 9 #>  #> $min_inclusive #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $max_inclusive #> [1] TRUE #>  # Returns: list(min=7, max=9, values=c(7,8,9), type="integer")  # Continuous ranges parse_range_notation("[18.5,25)") #> $type #> [1] "continuous" #>  #> $min #> [1] 18.5 #>  #> $max #> [1] 25 #>  #> $min_inclusive #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $max_inclusive #> [1] FALSE #>  # Returns: list(min=18.5, max=25, min_inclusive=TRUE, max_inclusive=FALSE, type="continuous")  parse_range_notation("[30,inf)") #> $type #> [1] "continuous" #>  #> $min #> [1] 30 #>  #> $max #> [1] Inf #>  #> $min_inclusive #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $max_inclusive #> [1] FALSE #>  # Returns: list(min=30, max=Inf, min_inclusive=TRUE, max_inclusive=FALSE, type="continuous")  # Special cases parse_range_notation("NA::a")   # Returns: list(type="special", value="NA::a") #> $type #> [1] "special" #>  #> $value #> [1] "NA::a" #>  parse_range_notation("copy")    # Returns: list(type="special", value="copy") #> $type #> [1] "special" #>  #> $value #> [1] "copy" #>  parse_range_notation("else")    # Returns: list(type="special", value="else") #> $type #> [1] "special" #>  #> $value #> [1] "else" #>

title: Parse variableStart field to extract raw variable name — parse_variable_start

title: Parse variableStart field to extract raw variable name — parse_variable_start
text: variable_start Character string variableStart field. Can contain multiple database specifications separated commas (e.g., "cycle1::age, cycle2::AGE"). cycle Character string specifying database/cycle extract (e.g., "cycle1", "cchs2001").

title: Parse variableStart field to extract raw variable name — parse_variable_start
text: Character string raw variable name, NULL found.

title: Parse variableStart field to extract raw variable name — parse_variable_start
text: function implements recodeflow-standard parsing strategies: Database-prefixed format: "database::varname" - database-specific names Bracket format (whole string): "[varname]" - database-agnostic names Bracket format (segment): "database1::var1, [var2]" - [var2] DEFAULT databases Plain format: "varname" - uses value -Important: [variable] represents DEFAULT databases explicitly referenced database:: notation. reduces repetition one databases use different variable names. DerivedVar format, returns NULL (requires custom derivation logic).

title: Parse variableStart field to extract raw variable name — parse_variable_start
code: # Database-prefixed format parse_variable_start("cycle1::height, cycle2::HEIGHT", "cycle1") #> [1] "height" # Returns: "height"  # Bracket format (database-agnostic) parse_variable_start("[gen_015]", "cycle1") #> [1] "gen_015" # Returns: "gen_015"  # Mixed format - [variable] is DEFAULT for databases not explicitly listed parse_variable_start("cycle1::amsdmva1, [ammdmva1]", "cycle2") #> [1] "ammdmva1" # Returns: "ammdmva1" (uses default for cycle2)  # Plain format parse_variable_start("bmi", "cycle1") #> [1] "bmi" # Returns: "bmi"  # No match for specified database parse_variable_start("cycle2::age", "cycle1") #> NULL # Returns: NULL

text: Validation checks: Required columns: uid, uid_detail, variable, recEnd Uniqueness: uid_detail values must unique Proportion validation: Values must range [0, 1] Population proportions (valid + missing codes) must sum 1.0 ±0.001 per variable Contamination proportions (corrupt_*) excluded sum Auto-normalizes warning sum ≠ 1.0 Parameter validation: Distribution-specific requirements: normal → mean + sd gompertz → rate + shape exponential → rate poisson → rate Link validation (config provided): uid values must exist config$uid Flexible recEnd validation: Warns error unknown recEnd values

title: Validate MockData configuration details against schema requirements including proportion sums and parameter completeness — validate_mock_data_config_details
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Validate details details <- read.csv("mock_data_config_details.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE) validate_mock_data_config_details(details)  # Validate with cross-check against config config <- read.csv("mock_data_config.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE) validate_mock_data_config_details(details, config = config) } # }
